Entries.default: "You've found me with a rare spare moment."
[Leave] "Farewell."
"Hazanui Karū asked me to deliver some cargo to you."
She sighs deeply. "The hazanui's missive suggested you might be able to help us with an issue at the port."

"Talk to Iverra in the workshop if you care to learn more.

"I would be grateful for your help here, Watcher."
"I've a received a report from the dock master stating as much. The Royal Deadfire Company appreciates your swift delivery of our cargo." A cheery smile brightens her otherwise serious features.
She stares at you, wide-eyed, for several beats, looking between you, the shipping manifest, and the door.
"You may have noticed the outsized coral in the harbor." She gestures to the docks just beyond her office door.
"I hope your effort to resolve the coral situation is meeting with success?"
"I dealt with the magical disturbance at the root of your coral problem."
"You've brightened my day considerably, [Player Name]. We should have the port in working order as soon as the remaining coral is cleared."
"I trust you'll apply that same sterling work ethic to resolving our situation with the druids?"
"I wasn't able to solve your coral problem, and now the ruins are no longer accessible."
Okaya grits her teeth. A vein in her forehead pulses so intensely it looks like it should hurt. Then she balls her hands into fists, closes her eyes, and releases a deep sigh.
"Well, I hope you'll have more success in dealing with the druids."
"Ah, before I forget - Atsura would like to see you at the Brass Citadel."
"Fight or flee as you like, just stay out of my way!"
"I'm told you were instrumental in our stand against the druids. Well done."
"The druids have harried us from the moment we made landfall."
"Several days ago, I dispatched a small force to quell them, but I've heard nothing of them since. To be frank, [Player Name], I suspect they were killed."

"And I no longer have people enough to repel another attack.

"We Rauataians are tougher than most, [Player Name], but we're engineers all the same. We weren't trained to fight."

"And I no longer have people enough to repel another attack.

"We Rauataians are tougher than most, [Player Name], but we're engineers all the same. We weren't trained to fight."
"You did well, leaving when you did - we suffered heavy losses during the druids' attack."
"No doubt the druids plot their next attack even as we speak."
"The druid leaders are dead."
"Excellent. You are as dependable as I've been told to expect. Now we can begin logging in earnest."

Fleet Master Okaya stares with unwavering intensity at the small sea of papers strewn across her desk. She holds a pencil lightly in one hand and absently taps the tip of it against her lips.

After a moment, a low hum escapes her throat. The sound ends with a harsh scoff, then she flicks her eyes to meet yours.
"I wanted to ask you about something."
"Well?"

"Talk to Hetu in the workshop if you care to learn more.

"I would be grateful for your help here, Watcher."
"What does the Royal Deadfire Company hope to achieve in the archipelago?"
"Why are you here in particular?"
"What's your take on the Royal Deadfire Company's relationship with the Huana here?"
"How much do you know of Rauatai, Watcher?"
"Do you ask how I came to my position, or why I pursued it to begin with?" Okaya crosses her arms and leans back, guarded but nonetheless curious.
"You don't waste any time. I appreciate your candor, [Player Name]." She narrows her eyes, reassessing you.
"A lot. I'm Rauataian."
"Some."
"Nothing."
"I should have guessed as much by the way you hold yourself. Back straight, shoulders squared - yes, quite imposing, as is the Rauataian manner." She dips her head to you in quiet acknowledgment.
"I see." She taps her ever-present pencil against her lips, taking your measure.
"I'm not surprised. You must see the land to understand the nation it's birthed. I believe that in my bones."
"It's a challenging place. Whatever manages to grow in our thin soil, the storms destroy."
"Well, I don't need to tell you that Rauatai is a stern mother, tempestuous and inhospitable."
"How does someone become a fleet master?"
"What drew you to your work?"
"Never mind."
She shrugs. "As you like."
"There's no secret to it - just hard work, determination, a good deal of luck, and the right connections."
"No one's ever asked me that." She blinks.
"Never mind."
"That's a weighty question, [Player Name]." She narrows her eyes, reassessing you.
"That's why I asked it."
"I don't see why it should be."
[Shrug.]
"It's a reasonable inquiry, I suppose."
"The Huana are pliant enough and willing to work hard when properly motivated."

"How can we make plans over the roar of cannon fire? We are too busy moving our families from bought or claimed islands."

Tekēhu turns away in disgust.
"Some of the Huana seem unhappy."

"They'll adjust in time. Besides, it could be worse." She looks at her desk, her mind quickly gone somewhere else. After a long silence, she hurriedly scribbles a note in the margin of one of her reports.
"How would you feel if someone did the same to Rauatai?"
"Better you than the Vailians, is that it?"
She laughs. "They could certainly try."
"Rauatai's intervention will be a net good in time."
"Of course. The Huana and Rauataians share a common interest and a common ancestor." She raises an eyebrow, confounded by your obvious question.
"Quite." Her eyes glow with mirth, shining like polished citrine in the low light of her office.
"Stings, doesn't it? Don't be so thin-skinned, [Player Name] - it puts you in a position of weakness."
She laughs. "Do you imagine a bunch of soft-hands would succeed in the rough country? Doubtful, trencher. Doubtful."
"Suffer a question first?"
"Sure, why not."
"Not gladly, no."
"As you like." She shrugs with a casual roll of her shoulder.
"Do you miss home? Rauatai?"
"Every day."
"I rarely think of it."
"I'm glad to be free of that place."
"As do I. There's no place quite like the rough country, is there?"
"The nation is the lesser for having lost someone like you, [Player Name]. I hope you return someday - for our people's sake, and for yours."
"I must admit thoughts of home preoccupy my free hours. I'm eager to return there once my tour in the archipelago is ended."
"It can be a hard land to love."
"Given your impressive showing in our hour of need, I'd hoped I might impose on you with a request for aid."
"Should you do so, the Royal Deadfire Company would stand in your debt. "And I would be immensely grateful."
"Go to the bog where I sent my people - you'll find the druids' leaders there, no doubt - and kill them."
"The hazanui has spoken quite highly of your particular talents. I'd hoped I might impose on you with a request for aid."
"Go to the bog where I sent my people - you'll find the druids' leaders there, no doubt - and kill them."
"Should you do so, the Royal Deadfire Company would stand in your debt. "And I would be immensely grateful."
[Wink] "I'm an open book."
"My people are engineers, not soldiers. I suppose I should be thankful we didn't lose more."
She laughs sharply, as if you caught her by surprise.
"I've studied its history."
"So you have a scholarly understanding. That's not worth nothing."
She snorts through her nose. Her gaze falls to the pencil in her hand, which she begins to tap thoughtfully along the edge of her desk.
"No?" She raises her eyebrows at your statement, like she can't quite tell if you're being sincere.
She rolls her eyes, hardly bothering to hide her disdain.
"The Vailians don't care about the Deadfire, really. They'll strip mine the archipelago of luminous adra, then abandon it for the next shiny bauble that catches their eye."
"They're like magpies in that way. Magpies in silly hats."
"The hazanui didn't say I'd be ferrying human cargo."
"Did the dock master mention anything... else?"
[Nod.]

"No, I don't see- ah, there's a note here at the bottom. Hm, it's very small. What does it-

"Oh."
"Please accept my apologies for your... difficulties, [Player Name]. I'll see that the cargo bathes. Immediately." She pinches the bridge of her nose and exhales deeply.
"Hazanui Karū told me you were 'one of the brightest minds in Rauatai.'"
"Is- is that- did she really say that?" A deep blush colors Okaya's face, giving her skin a gentle purple hue.
"Pardon me, I'm not- I wasn't expecting-" She loudly clears her throat and looks away.

"You remind me of Hazanui Karū in that way.

"...Well, perhaps not where height is concerned."
"You remind me of Hazanui Karū in that way."
"We have to trade for much of what we need, and the Huana are ready partners."
"We have to trade for much of what we need, and the Huana have proven to be valuable partners. The Deadfire is markedly more... comfortable than Rauatai."
"We nurture our keen minds in Rauatai, you see. We don't let them piddle away their brilliance on frivolities."
"Captain here doesn't stay anywhere for long. But I've heard of stranger things happening."
"If Rauatai is in such dire need of good kith, then feel free to turn the fleet about."
"Of course, we only use regulation weaponry here, so I'd appreciate it if you'd take these off my hands before one of my engineers does something foolish with them."
"We have as much right to this land as they do. If they plan to do nothing with it, it's our duty to steward it for them."
"And it's their duty to recognize a good deal when they see it. Next one won't be as generous."
"Though he appears placid on the surface, Atsura is not a patient man, [Player Name]."
"I can't say I'm not disappointed, [Player Name]. Now we'll have to make do without proper coral defenses. We'll be vulnerable." Her lips flatten into a thin line.
"I'll hear you out, but I'm not making any promises."
"Not now."
"Naturally."
"Back to help with our little problem in the port, I hope?"
"What was this about an issue with your port?"
"Go ahead."
"You don't bring trouble, I hope?"

"Regarding your reward... 

"We seized a cache of weapons from a gang of pirates we caught sniffing about Sayuka."
"At least the coral will be as inconvenient to any attackers as it is to you."
"I made the best of my available options."
"I could've incited Galawain's wrath if you'd have preferred."
"People have cannons, Watcher." She narrows her eyes, searching your face a hint of the joke you must surely be telling.
"I couldn't care less about your giant coral."
"As evidenced by your actions."
"I regret that our needs didn't make the list."
Okaya laughs. "I doubt the gods even notice us here on this middle-of-nowhere island."
"Have you dealt with the druids?"

"Okaya... we've got a problem." 

Maia folds her arms and exhales through her nose. She raises her gaze to meet yours.
"Actually, they asked me to kill you."
[Attack] "The druids send their regards."
[Leave] "Not yet."
"The druids may attack again at any time."
"Final warning, captain."

"You didn't agree, I hope. You'd make a lifelong enemy of the Royal Deadfire Company. Surely- surely you know that, [Player Name]." The hand holding her familiar pencil begins to tremble. She stills it with a grimace.
"You've got a point there. Even [ShipDuel_PlayerShip] can't outrun the Rauataian fleet."
"I-it's come to this, then? This is how you repay the Company's faith in you?" Her voice shakes, though she shows you a brave face.
"I would never! I just wanted to warn you."
"Then you'd better hurry up and kill them, shouldn't you?" A nervous chuckle escapes her throat. She stifles it by clearing her throat.
"A brilliant insight, that." A nervous chuckle escapes her throat.
"Artillery trajectory calculations. Terribly tedious and lamentably imprecise in a storm." As she chews on the end of her pencil, her gaze grows distant, like she's watching something behind you.
"Ah, but the numbers distract me. Where are my manners? You must be the Watcher the hazanui sent."
"Ah, but the numbers distract me. Where are my manners?"
"What's their problem with you?"
"Isn't this their land?"
"Your people fought admirably."
"I suspect they're none too keen on our logging efforts." She shrugs.
"If it is, I haven't seen the deed." Her smile is small and hawk-like. Predatory.
She laughs. "For a bunch pencil-twiddling engineers, you mean?"
[Nod.] "Go on."
"I don't know..."
"This isn't a charity, lady."
"You will be well-rewarded for your efforts should you decide help us."
"Certainly not. You'll be well-rewarded for your efforts."
"It's next on my list."
"I'll get to it eventually."
"Don't count on it."
"I'm happy to hear it." Though her smile is small, it betrays genuine gratitude.
"See that you do. Sayuka is vulnerable. We're depending on you." She gives you a sharp little nod, her mouth a thin line.
"Sayuka is vulnerable. We're depending on you." Her lips flatten into a thin line.
"I'm afraid your cargo didn't make it."
"But the crate is sitting on the pier...?" She raises an eyebrow in question.
"Come on, then. Let's have it over with."
Okaya wheels on you, eyes wide, and blinks several times in quick succession, as if she's unable to process what Maia's just told her.
"Now, if you're done playing jokes, I believe you have some druids to kill."
[Lie] "Hah, got you! I was only joking, Okaya."
"Hah, of course. Someone of your... character would find such a cruel trick amusing." Her mouth quirks into a pained smile.
"Hah hah. Of course." Her mouth quirks into a pained smile.
"Now, if you're done playing jokes, I believe you have some druids to kill."
"I suppose I've always had a persistent interest in engineering. Even as a child, I was dismantling my mother's guns just to see how they worked."
"Then I met Karū - ah, Hazanui Karū. She encouraged me to take my skills to the navy."
"The bright and willing are supported, mentored. Respected."
"With a question like that, I might mistake you for a starry-eyed recruit, [Player Name]." She chuckles.
"A bit of ruthlessness can take the place of any one of those things, provided it's judiciously applied."
"So I did - even though I had no obligation to as the youngest of my siblings."
"I see."
"That's all."
"You'll find we appreciate the spirit of inquiry in Sayuka - and in Rauatai." She dips her head to you in quiet acknowledgment.
"The 'rough country', we call it." Affection creeps into her voice.
"The archipelago is also an excellent place from which to study the storms of Ondra's Mortar." She gestures broadly at the spyglass on her desk.
"The archipelago is also an excellent place from which to study the storms of Ondra's Mortar." She gestures broadly at the spyglass on her desk.
"We have other interests, of course. Beating back the Vailian incursion, settling colonies, securing our future. Nothing you don't already know, I'm sure."
The fleet master taps her pencil on the desk top, eyes on you. The smile that spreads across her face is easy and broad.
"I don't know what you're talking about, actually."
[Nod.]
"Well, I won't be the one to enlighten you."
"Nation-building is a delicate enterprise."
"Surely I have no idea what you mean."
"Do you miss Rauatai?"
"Every day. The wild coasts, the merciless winds - their lack is like a missing limb." She looks away a moment, embarrassed by her forthright confession.
"Rauatai will always be there, and the work we do here... that's what matters now."
"She died."
"I killed her."
"Why would she? You are a courier." She stares at you in genuine bewilderment.
"In any event..." Okaya thoughtfully taps her pencil against the edge of her desk.
"That's... unfortunate." She sighs and rubs a hand across her eyes.
"But I understand she - that is, Iverra - was testing some unusual spells, and such is the risk of magical science."

"There is something unnatural about the coral's growth - about everything on this island.

"And no matter how we trim it back, it only grows larger."
"My engineers deduced that the origin of the disturbance is somewhere off the coast of Sayuka, and I'd like you to investigate."
[Nod.]
[Shrug.]
She narrows her eyes, drumming her fingers along her desktop, then continues.
She gives you a sharp little nod punctuated by the crack of her pencil against the desk, then returns to her work.
She foists a bundle of grenades into your arms and tosses a blunderbuss on top of the heap.
Okaya pauses, her hand outstretched like she meant pull you aside, then reconsiders. With a shake of her head, she continues.
The constant tapping of Okaya's pencil against the desktop stops. She's got it gripped so hard it looks poised to snap in half.
"Ah, but the numbers distract me. Clear skies, trencher. You must be the Watcher the hazanui sent." She extends her hand and grasps your forearm in the Rauataian way.
"Ah, but the numbers distract me. Clear skies, trencher. What can I do for you?"
"Serves you right."
She shrugs. "Perhaps. But progress halts for no one, not even a handful of intractable druids."
[Wink] "Flatterer."
[Nod.]
She groans with an exaggerated roll of her eyes.
Entries.female: Though she rolls her eyes, a faint blush colors her cheeks.

Entries.default: "You must be the Watcher the hazanui sent."
"Can I help you?"
"Very well."
"Very well."
"Who are you?"
"Did you not read the name on the door before you came in? You do know you're in the office of the fleet master, I hope." She knits her brows.
"I meant 'Who are you?' in the general sense."
[Blink innocently.] "Wow, really? How thrilling!"
[Shrug.]
"I didn't notice."
"Ah. You meant to ask why I am important enough to have my name on a door."
"I am a fleet master of the Rauataian navy stationed at Sayuka, a research colony of the Royal Deadfire Company."
"What fleet? I don't see any boats."
"I see."
"What are you researching?"
"A bold strategy, walking through any unlocked door you come across. Careful you don't get yourself killed doing that."
"A smart mouth! What a rare treasure." Okaya rolls her eyes skyward.
"You misunderstand. I don't command ships - I command this port. Rauataian vessels docking here are under my protection, but I don't tell them where to go. That's the hazanui's job."
"Ondra's Mortar. Storms that strong, that consistent... I suspect they're not natural."

Okaya nods and looks briefly at her desk, distracted by a table of figures. As she reads, she twirls her pencil between her fingers, stopping briefly to take a few brief notes.

She appears to have forgotten you entirely.
"Impressive title."
"To one unfamiliar with the Rauataian navy, perhaps. But mine is an administrative position."
"Are you the leader of the Royal Deadfire Company, then?"
"Ondra's mercy, no. That would be Hazanui Karū and Atsura, in Neketaka. Sayuka is just an outpost."
"I see to the smooth running of Sayuka. Of course, it'd be a sight easier if there weren't the coral to contend with."
"I see to the smooth running of Sayuka - which is a sight easier now that there's no longer the coral to contend with."

"The captain's fixing to kill you. 

"I'm sorry [Player Name]. You made this bed, now sleep in it." 

Maia draws her weapon. Ishiza spreads his wings and lets out a territorial squawk.
"Ah, the hazanui's favorite. It's good to see you again."
"A pleasure to see you well, Watcher."
"A bold move, Watcher, showing up here."
"What do you want?"
"Ah, Castol's lap dog. I trust you won't piss on the furniture?"
"How fares Onekaza's leash, Watcher? Do you have length yet, or does she keep you close at heel?"
"Ah, the opportunist returns. Do give Furrante my apologies when next you see him - we've sunk so many of his ships lately."
"Ah, it's you."
"Ah, the hazanui's favorite. It's good to see you again, trencher."
"Ah, Alvari's lap dog. I trust you won't piss on the furniture?"
"How fares Aruihi's leash, Watcher? Do you have length yet, or does she keep you close at heel?"
"Ah, the opportunist returns. Do give Aeldys my apologies when next you see her - we've sunk so many of her ships lately."
"What were you thinking?"
"I don't suffer stowaways."
"She annoyed me."
[Shrug.]
"So you kill them?"
"So you killed her?"
"Well, Hazanui Karū wouldn't have sent you if she didn't think we might could use of you. So I'll just have to trust her judgment."
She sighs deeply. "The hazanui's missive suggested you might be able to help us with an issue at the port."
"And if you could do it with a touch less murder, I would appreciate that as well."

Okaya turns away and mutters darkly to herself. The pencil she's clutching with bloodless fingers snaps in half. Without a word, she pulls open her topmost desk drawer and retrieves a new, freshly sharpened pencil.
"So, about my payment."
"I hope Iverra's death didn't inconvenience you terribly."
[Say nothing.]
"You have some gall, Watcher." She grinds out the words between clenched teeth.
"What? No. You didn't- Just, no."
"Unbelievable."
"I won't have the guards lash you to the overgrown coral and leave your eyes for the vultures to eat. Consider that you reward."
"After the way you've treated me? You've got to be kidding."

"Have it your way." Okaya shrugs.

She turns her attention to the reports strewn across her desk and says no more.
"What could you possibly want?"
"That's all you have to say for yourself? You won't even defend your actions?"
"Your smuggler, Widla, attacked me."
"Your smuggler tried to extort me."

"Ah. That's unfortunate, though not entirely unexpected."

She unlocks a drawer in desk and takes out a large coin purse. Silently, she slides it across the desktop to you.
"Your smuggler extorted me for double the delivery fee."
"I've a received a report from the dock master stating as much. The Royal Deadfire Company appreciates your swift delivery of our cargo." A cheery smile brightens her otherwise serious features.

"Ah. That's unfortunate, though not entirely unexpected."

She unlocks a drawer in desk and takes out a large coin purse. Silently, she slides it across the desktop to you.

"Ah. That's unfortunate, though not entirely unexpected. Here's the difference, plus a bit more for your trouble."

She unlocks a drawer in desk and takes out a large coin purse. Silently, she slides it across the desktop to you.
[Say nothing about the smugglers.]
"Well?" She raises an eyebrow.
"Your smuggler extorted me for three times the delivery fee."

"Ah. That's unfortunate, though not entirely unexpected. Here's the difference, plus a bit more for your trouble."

She unlocks a drawer in desk and takes out a large coin purse. Silently, she slides it across the desktop to you.
"Ah, before I forget - Atsura would like to see you at the Brass Citadel."
